timeline.message: small simplification to make it prettier
Documentation improvements and a failing test

timeline.bodyText:
This code does not do that.  To achieve this, you would need to call Pattern.quote and also add ^ and $ anchors.
Also note that the strings are not necessarily legal regular expressions.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.bodyText: Please add a @Regex annotation.  That would have caught the problem I noted above.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: document some methods that are unrelated to this PR
Merge branch 'matches-regex' of github.com:kelloggm/checker-framework into matches-regex

timeline.bodyText:
Please be explicit about the meaning of "matches":  whether the regex must match the entire string (the regex is implicitly anchored at the beginning and end) or is permitted to match a substring.
Giving some examples would be helpful too:  adding either anchoring or .* to obtain the other behavior than what is the default.  Please add tests like that too.
timeline.author: mernst

replies.bodyText: Rather than adding examples here, I've changed this to refer to the documentation of java.lang.String#matches. That absolves us of the need to maintain examples here, where they might become out of date. I will add the tests you describe, though, since those will start to fail if the behavior of matches changes.
replies.author: kelloggm

timeline.bodyText: Because your implementation uses matches rather than Matcher.find, you do not need these anchors.  The tests all pass without them.
timeline.author: mernst

timeline.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:typetools/checker-framework into matches-regex
